column2: Java is a high-level, object-oriented programming language developed by Sun Microsystems (now owned by Oracle).
The JVM (Java Virtual Machine) is an abstract machine that executes Java bytecode.
Bytecode is the intermediate representation of Java code that is executed by the JVM.
The JDK (Java Development Kit) is a software development environment used to develop Java applications.
The JRE (Java Runtime Environment) provides the libraries and JVM required to run Java programs.

column1: What is the difference between JDK and JRE?
column2: JDK is for development (includes compiler and tools), while JRE is only for running Java programs.

column1: What is a class in Java?
column2: A class is a blueprint for creating objects, defining properties and behaviors.

column1: What is an object in Java?
column2: An object is an instance of a class, with state (fields) and behavior (methods).

column1: What is the main method in Java?
column2: public static void main(String[] args) is the entry point of a Java application.

column1: What is the difference between == and .equals()?
column2: == compares references, while .equals() compares object content (if overridden).

column1: What is a constructor in Java?
column2: A constructor is a special method used to initialize objects when they are created.

column1: Can a constructor return a value?
column2: No, constructors do not have return types, not even void.
Method overloading allows multiple methods with the same name but different parameters.
Method overriding allows a subclass to provide a specific implementation of a superclass method.
Inheritance allows a class (subclass) to inherit fields and methods from another class (superclass).
Polymorphism allows one interface to be used for multiple forms (method overloading and overriding).
Encapsulation is the mechanism of bundling data (fields) and methods that operate on them into a single unit (class).
Abstraction hides complex implementation details and shows only essential features.

column1: What is an interface in Java?
column2: An interface is a reference type that contains abstract methods (Java 8+ allows default/static methods).

column1: Can an interface have instance variables?
column2: No, interfaces can only have public static final (constant) variables.

column1: What is the difference between an abstract class and an interface?
column2: An abstract class can have concrete methods and fields, while an interface originally couldn't (until Java 8).

column1: What is a package in Java?
column2: A package is a namespace that organizes related classes and interfaces.

column1: What is the default value of a local variable in Java?
column2: Local variables do not have default values
column3: they must be initialized before use.

column1: What is the final keyword in Java?
column2: final can be applied to variables (constant), methods (cannot be overridden), and classes (cannot be inherited).

column1: What is the static keyword in Java?
column2: static denotes class-level fields/methods (shared across instances) or static blocks.

column1: What is a static block in Java?
column2: A static block is used for static initialization of a class (executed when the class is loaded).

column1: What is an instance block in Java?
column2: An instance block runs before the constructor each time an object is created.

column1: What is the super keyword in Java?
column2: super refers to the parent class's members or constructor.

column1: What is the this keyword in Java?
column2: this refers to the current object instance.

column1: What is a singleton class in Java?
column2: A singleton class ensures only one instance exists and provides global access to it.

column1: How is a singleton class implemented?
column2: By making the constructor private, providing a static method to return the single instance.

column1: What is an enum in Java?
column2: An enum is a special data type that defines a set of named constants.
Autoboxing converts a primitive type to its corresponding wrapper class automatically (e.g., int to Integer).
Unboxing converts a wrapper class object back to its primitive type (e.g., Integer to int).

column1: What are wrapper classes in Java?
column2: Wrapper classes (e.g., Integer, Double) allow primitives to be used as objects.

column1: What is the difference between int and Integer?
column2: int is a primitive, while Integer is a wrapper class with additional methods.

column1: What is a String in Java?
column2: A String is an immutable sequence of characters represented by the String class.

column1: Why is String immutable in Java?
column2: For security, thread safety, and optimization (e.g., string pooling).

column1: What is the difference between String, StringBuilder, and StringBuffer?
column2: String is immutable
column3: StringBuilder is mutable and not thread-safe

column1: What is exception handling in Java?
column2: Exception handling manages runtime errors using try, catch, finally, throw, and throws.

column1: What is the difference between checked and unchecked exceptions?
column2: Checked exceptions must be declared/handled (e.g., IOException), while unchecked exceptions (RuntimeException) do not.
It automatically closes resources (like streams) that implement AutoCloseable.
throws declares exceptions that a method might throw, shifting handling responsibility to the caller.
throw explicitly throws an exception (e.g., throw new IllegalArgumentException()).
finally executes code regardless of whether an exception occurs (used for cleanup).
Yes, if System.exit() is called or the JVM crashes.
A user-defined exception by extending Exception or RuntimeException.
Multithreading allows concurrent execution of multiple threads within a process.

column1: How is a thread created in Java?
column2: By extending Thread class or implementing Runnable (preferred).

column1: What is the difference between Thread.start() and Thread.run()?
column2: start() launches a new thread, while run() executes in the current thread.
Synchronization controls thread access to shared resources to prevent race conditions.
A deadlock occurs when two or more threads wait indefinitely for each other's locks.
volatile ensures a variable is read from/written to main memory (not CPU cache).
transient excludes a field from serialization.
Serialization converts an object into a byte stream for storage/transmission.
Deserialization reconstructs an object from a byte stream.
Comparable defines natural ordering (compareTo method).
Comparator allows custom sorting (compare method).
Generics enable type-safe collections (e.g., List<String>).
Type erasure removes generic type info at runtime for backward compatibility.
A lambda is an anonymous function (e.g., (a, b) -> a + b).
An interface with one abstract method (e.g., Runnable, Comparator).
@Override indicates a method is intended to override a superclass method.

column1: What is the diamond operator (<>) in Java?
column2: The diamond operator infers generic types (e.g., List<String> list = new ArrayList<>()).
var (Java 10+) allows local variable type inference (e.g., var list = new ArrayList<String>()).
Streams process sequences of elements (e.g., filtering, mapping) in a functional style.
Optional avoids null checks by wrapping potentially null values.

column1: What is the difference between List and Set?
column2: List allows duplicates and maintains order
column3: Set forbids duplicates (no order, unless LinkedHashSet).

column1: What is the difference between ArrayList and LinkedList?
column2: ArrayList uses a dynamic array (fast access)

column1: What is the difference between HashMap and HashTable?
column2: HashMap is not thread-safe and allows nulls
column3: HashTable is synchronized and does not allow nulls.

column1: What is hashCode() and equals() contract?
column2: If two objects are equal, their hash codes must be equal (but not vice versa).

column1: What is the difference between fail-fast and fail-safe iterators?
column2: Fail-fast throws ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration
Reflection inspects/modifies class/object behavior at runtime (e.g., Class.forName()).

column1: What is the module system in Java?
column2: Modules (Java 9+) define dependencies and encapsulate packages.
JShell (Java 9+) is an interactive REPL for Java code snippets.

column1: What is a record in Java?
column2: A record (Java 14+) is a concise class for immutable data (auto-generates equals, hashCode, etc.).
A sealed class (Java 17+) restricts which classes can extend/implement it.

column1: What is the difference between throw and throws?
column2: throw raises an exception
column3: throws declares possible exceptions in a method signature.

column1: What is the difference between final, finally, and finalize?
column2: final is a modifier
column4: finalize() is a method called before garbage collection.

column1: What is garbage collection in Java?
column2: Garbage collection automatically reclaims memory from unreachable objects.

column1: What is the difference between System.gc() and Runtime.gc()?
column2: Both suggest JVM run GC, but Runtime.gc() is more direct (System.gc() calls it).

column1: What are the four main OOP principles?
column2: Encapsulation, Abstraction, Inheritance, and Polymorphism.
An empty interface (e.g., Serializable) used to mark classes for special behavior.

column1: What is the difference between deep copy and shallow copy?
column2: Deep copy duplicates all nested objects

column1: What is the ClassLoader in Java?
column2: ClassLoader loads classes dynamically into the JVM.

column1: What is the difference between break and continue?
column2: break exits a loop
column3: continue skips to the next iteration.

column1: What is the difference between while and do-while?
column2: while checks condition first
A shorthand for if-else (e.g., result = (a > b) ? a : b).
instanceof checks if an object is an instance of a class/interface.

column1: What is the difference between & and &&?
column2: & is a bitwise AND

column1: What is the difference between | and ||?
column2: | is a bitwise OR
Annotations provide metadata (e.g., @Override, @Deprecated).
Dependency injection provides objects (dependencies) to a class externally (e.g., via Spring).
Spring is a framework for enterprise Java applications (DI, MVC, etc.).
Hibernate is an ORM (Object-Relational Mapping) tool for database operations.
Maven is a build automation and dependency management tool.

column1: What is the difference between JDBC and JPA?
column2: JDBC is a low-level SQL API
column3: JPA is a higher-level ORM specification (e.g., Hibernate).

column2: A servlet is a Java class that handles HTTP requests/responses (used in web apps).
JavaServer Pages (JSP) embed Java code in HTML for dynamic web content.
A reusable solution to common software design problems (e.g., Singleton, Factory).
Ensures a class has only one instance with global access.
Creates objects without specifying the exact class (uses a factory method).
Defines a one-to-many dependency between objects (e.g., event handling).
Constructs complex objects step-by-step (e.g., StringBuilder).

column1: What is the difference between REST and SOAP?
column2: REST is stateless, uses HTTP/JSON
Spring Boot simplifies Spring app setup with auto-configuration and embedded servers.
An architecture where applications are composed of small, independent services.
